question: Which phase of wound healing begins immediately after injury?
short_explanation: The inflammatory phase begins first to control bleeding and prevent infection.
long_explanation: The inflammatory phase initiates the healing cascade. It involves vasoconstriction, platelet aggregation, and infiltration of neutrophils to manage bleeding and prevent pathogen entry.
clinical_application: Massage is contraindicated during this stage due to acute inflammation and tissue instability.
text: Which phase of wound healing begins immediately after injury?

question: What key cellular activity dominates the proliferative phase?
short_explanation: Fibroblast proliferation helps form granulation tissue and extracellular matrix.
long_explanation: Fibroblasts produce type III collagen and lay down the extracellular matrix. This supports angiogenesis and epithelialization, central to wound filling and tissue regrowth.
clinical_application: Gentle massage can assist with circulation during this stage but must avoid disrupting fragile granulation tissue.
text: What key cellular activity dominates the proliferative phase?

question: During which phase is angiogenesis most active?
short_explanation: Angiogenesis occurs primarily during the proliferative phase.
long_explanation: New blood vessels form to support metabolically active tissue regrowth. VEGF and fibroblast activity play central roles in revascularization.
clinical_application: Tissue may appear red and fragile due to increased vascularity; care must be taken in therapy.
text: During which phase is angiogenesis most active?

question: What signals the start of the maturation (remodeling) phase?
short_explanation: Scar contraction indicates the transition into remodeling.
long_explanation: The remodeling phase is marked by conversion of type III to type I collagen, decreased vascularity, and wound contraction through myofibroblast action.
clinical_application: Massage during this phase may support scar pliability and function if applied correctly.
text: What signals the start of the maturation (remodeling) phase?

question: Which protein replaces type III collagen in the final scar?
short_explanation: Type I collagen provides tensile strength in mature scars.
long_explanation: Initial repair uses type III collagen, which is gradually replaced by stronger type I collagen to restore tissue integrity.
clinical_application: Scar work aims to improve elasticity where excess type I collagen causes stiffness.
text: Which protein replaces type III collagen in the final scar?

question: Which cells are first to arrive at the wound site during the inflammatory phase?
short_explanation: Neutrophils are first responders in wound healing.
long_explanation: Neutrophils arrive within minutes to phagocytose bacteria and debris, setting the stage for subsequent immune and tissue repair processes.
clinical_application: Early inflammation signs like redness and swelling reflect neutrophil activity; massage is contraindicated.
text: Which cells are first to arrive at the wound site during the inflammatory phase?

question: What role do macrophages play in wound healing?
answers: They clean debris and signal repair
short_explanation: Macrophages clean debris and signal fibroblasts to start repair.
long_explanation: Macrophages follow neutrophils and orchestrate healing by clearing dead cells and secreting growth factors like TGF-Î², stimulating fibroblast and angiogenic activity.
clinical_application: Massage during late inflammation or early proliferation must accommodate fragile tissue and immune activity.
text: What role do macrophages play in wound healing?

correctAnswer: They clean debris and signal repair
abcd: C. They clean debris and signal repair

question: Which of the following best describes granulation tissue?
short_explanation: Granulation tissue is rich in capillaries and fibroblasts.
long_explanation: It consists of proliferating fibroblasts, new capillaries, and ECM, providing the foundation for epithelial repair.
clinical_application: Avoid friction over granulation tissue to prevent bleeding or tissue damage.
text: Which of the following best describes granulation tissue?

question: What determines whether wound healing is primary or secondary intention?
answers: Size and cleanliness of the wound
short_explanation: Wound size and edge approximation determine healing mode.
long_explanation: Clean wounds with close edges heal by primary intention, while larger or contaminated wounds heal by secondary intention with more granulation tissue and scarring.
clinical_application: Massage therapists must adapt techniques based on scar maturity and healing mode.
text: What determines whether wound healing is primary or secondary intention?

correctAnswer: Size and cleanliness of the wound
